steps.text: Construct buildings with preventive design for pest management.
Maintain building to prevent pest entry.
Maintain daily pest management programs.
Address pests from facility and surrounding areas.
Follow federal and state regulations.
Design buildings for pest prevention.
Maintain short grass and trimmed shrubs.
Install paved access and proper drainage.
Create a gravel strip around the foundation.
Place night-lights at least 30 feet away from doors.
Keep framing at least four inches from walls.
Fill necessary voids with materials like polyurethane foam.
Use concrete, brick, or tile walls.
Seal and clean wall materials.
Avoid hollow panel-type walls or make them well-sealed.
Use smooth, free-standing water roofs.
Limit the number of windows and use transparent glass block.
Use metal, tight-fitting doors.
Install air curtains at large doors.
Use good lighting with dust-tight fixtures.
Install electrical and plumbing services for easy access and cleaning.
Make control panels insect-proof.
Equipment should be roomy, accessible for cleaning, and raised at least six inches off the floor.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass.
Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage and outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs.
Use electrified grids inside for insect attraction.
Rodent-proof all openings.
Screen windows.
Block bird access to ledges.
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Use rodent traps near doors.
Ensure proper sanitation.
Use rodent bait stations where policy permits.
Use space treatments with nonresiduals, crack and crevice treatments with residuals, spot treatments, and fumigation for raw commodities.
Form an inspection committee and assign roles.
Conduct a thorough inspection of the plant.
Record all defects and distribute notes to department heads.
Departments correct identified defects.
Committee reviews notes, addresses uncorrected items, and assigns correction dates.
Sanitation is the responsibility of everyone in the plant.
Inspect places using a flashlight to detect insect trails or mouse footprints.
Observe suspect stock by spreading it on a flat surface and watching for movement.
Inspect areas most likely to produce results, such as under and inside equipment.
Suspect any unaccounted-for voids in equipment or structures.
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices.
Reward good sanitation to encourage plant-wide cooperation.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm for a fresh perspective.
Check temperature drops and their impact on mortality.
Implement good sanitation and temperature control.
Minimize insects' movement by inspecting incoming materials.
Design buildings to minimize entry points.
Use visual inspection for monitoring.
Consider using yellow or sodium arc lights outdoors.
Place traps based on season and temperature profiles.
Examine trends in trap catches over time.
Identify common insect pests in raw and processed food.
Select appropriate trap types based on environment.
Place traps on facility perimeter for outdoor pest control.
Determine trap placement and interpretation strategy.
Implement a pest management plan for the popcorn and seed industry.
Read the label carefully.
Identify food and non-food areas.
Understand types of residual applications: general, spot, and crack & crevice.
Check for pesticide regulations in your state.
Identify life cycle stages of beetles and moths: egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
Understand that beetle larvae do not have legs on the back half of their body.
Recognize that moth larvae have legs on the back half of their body.
Determine that adults of both species have chewing mouthparts and feed on food.
Identify moth species: Almond Moth, Indianmeal Moth, Mediterranean Flour Moth, Mealmoth.
Check for signs of larvae or webbing.
Inspect for beetle species: Lesser Grain Borer, Cigarette Beetle, Drugstore Beetle, Confused Flour Beetle, Red Flour Beetle, Sawtoothed Grain Beetle, Merchant Grain Beetle, Foreign Grain Beetle.
Apply control methods: Avoidance, sanitation, heat treatment, cold treatment, residual insecticides, space sprays, fumigation.
Identify pests: Spider Beetles, Warehouse Beetle / Dermestid Beetles, Cockroaches, Flies, Ants, Bees and Wasps, Booklice.
Determine pest behaviors and preferred environments.
Implement control measures based on pest behavior and environment.
Monitor for signs of infestation or re-infestation.
Identify locations with potential pest issues: silverfish, firebrats, crickets, ground beetles, sowbugs, and pillbugs.
Understand rodent behavior: senses, reactions, agility.
Recognize signs of rodents and other pests: droppings, runways, rubmarks, burrows, tracks, urine.
Implement sanitation and habitat modification strategies.
Rodent-proof construction: seal openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice and 1/2 inch for rats.
Use compressed air sprayer for crack and crevice, spot, and application.
Select appropriate nozzle for desired application.
Check nozzles and select appropriate type based on spray pattern.
Clean dusters after use.
Maintain space treating equipment by checking for proper function and selecting appropriate type based on application.
Wear appropriate respiratory protection as indicated on the label.
Obtain NIOSH approval number.
Ensure proper fit.
Perform daily pressure checks.
Avoid wearing beards.

constraints.text: Thorough inspections must be conducted and all defects recorded.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls for inspection in warehouses.
A written inspection procedure for incoming raw products is required by law.
Monitor temperature drops to prevent high mortality.
Minimize insects' movement to prevent infestations.
Identify common insect pests in raw and processed food before implementing trapping strategies.
Match trap types to the environment for effective pest control.
Place traps on the facility perimeter to intercept and predict indoor infestations.
Ensure pesticides are used according to their labels and applicable regulations.
Ensure proper identification before applying pesticides to prevent harming beneficial insects or non-target organisms.
Check for signs of infestation before consuming or selling food products.
Properly store food products to prevent infestations.
Ensure proper pest identification before implementing control measures.
Maintain cleanliness and sanitation to prevent infestations.
Effective pest control requires understanding the behavior and signs of various pests.
Sanitation and habitat modification are essential for reducing rodent populations.
Properly maintain equipment for safety and effectiveness.
Wear appropriate respiratory protection when handling pesticides.
